Hey, I know this might a long shot but I'm wondering if you would be willing to answer a couple questions for a school English project I'm doing? I'm a big fan of your music and from reading your answers here and watching the reality videos, I feel like you might have some insightful things to say on this topic.

Essentially I'm writing an essay comparing digital music production to a "selfie": they are both ways of capturing a moment in time, who you were as well as the world around you, then sharing it with people around the world through the internet. I was wondering if you could share some of your own experience with this so that I could include it in my writing? I have a couple questions:

1. Could you explain how your experiences and personality at the time shaped the music you create, and how did your music change over time as you changed a person?

as i get more experience, i can get better, but then that makes me get more attached to how good i think it's going, and then i get more afraid to take risks, so that creates a temporary problem. then i get desperate and snap and take more risks and it gets good again. this cycle repeats on all variations of timescales, long and short. even within 1 day
2. Do you think self-expression through music has changed at all with the advent of online music sharing, compared to before the internet, and if so how?
i was going to say yes but now that i think about it no

3. In many ways, the music you create is an extension of yourself. Is it tough to put your music out there and be vulnerable in front of a wide audience which can now comment and give (potentially negative) feedback easily and quickly?
the only thing more scary than doing it is not doing it

What is the universe?
the word 'universe' is pretty much meant to mean the entire world you are living in, expanded out to the farthest extent possible
Is it an object in another, larger existence?

if so, then you'd have to switch what you're calling 'universe' and start calling that larger thing the universe. Or you could just keep chasing new names, each time claiming that the new name really means the whole thing
If it isn't, and the universe is all that is and everything that exists is inside it, what IS it?
in that case, it would be everything
It has a boundary, we know (roughly) how big it is, and that it's expanding.

i think it's a decent logical assumption to assume that it has no size (infinite), but i don't really think anyone can prove that. and you certainly can't see or measure all of it. the amount of it which we can see has been measured. but that's not the size of the whole universe, that's just the size we can see, which is known as the 'observable' universe. right now pretty much no one can see further, but that's not a 'space' boundary, it's actually more of a time boundary. looking that far a way looks back in time, and for some reason there is actually a problem with looking back more than 13.8 bil years.... something gets weird and there's like a desktop background of some sort
WHAT IS IT EXPANDING INTO?

there is an expanding sensation happening. but it's not clear how to define or explain that. everything seems to be getting further away from each other. but then again, the earth feels like it's accelerating up under us, but that would be backwards for the other side of the planet,... and it's not. So there is clearly something relativistic going on in both cases that is possibly a next level of whacky that no one has quite nailed down yet. but these things always get found and learned eventually. even the weird ones

I have years of stuff that I never put up because I'm waiting for the right moment. There's still more work I want to do, lots of the songs feel unfinished, and for the ones that feel finished I have more work I want to do on them (like better mixing etc). I described here comes the sun (specifically 0:17 with the chairs) as having "hard, uneven lighting that communicates a sense of disorder to audiences" in a Media project. Is this true, or is something else being communicated?

the objective was to explore the dank 3D space in any way i can, without being sucked into the vortex of spending 500 years in the project. 500 to 1000 years is probably the natural amount to be stuck in a 3D project, in order to reasonably explore at least all the basic options for the material. And that's probably many times longer than my entire life span, so clearly some drastic drastic measures need to be taken, urgently, constantly, in order to taper that down to not only something that fits within 1 lifetime, but several times during 1 lifetime (i'm a multi-video kinda guy). So, ...... you grab some cubes, grab some chairs, stack them up, throw some lights, move the camera, .... and even just 1 of those things individually would be enough send you into a 25-year wormhole. so a "shut up and go" strategy has to be rapidly and rigorously invoked, again and again and again

while reading the lyrics in the questions the last few days, i noticed how vividly i had remembered your songs. as i read the words on the screen i instantly heard the melody and a whole bunch of the other stuff really easily. now i don't have perfect pitch, but when i went and checked the songs to see i was always exactly on pitch as well. this happens to me sometimes with other people's songs when i play them in my head (which i do all the time) but with yours it seems i have a much better chance. usually i can't tell at all if i'm playing a song in the wrong key in my head though, but reading your lyrics made it super vivid. it's not that i think they have to be in one key, but when i hear you singing it in my head it my memory is just especially vivid. i think i remember you saying you always do a range test for your songs. might this be part of it?

no, i think what's happening is you have very strong sonic memory of these recordings, probably because you've heard them a lot. i've noticed that it's pretty common for people to remember the absolute pitch of familiar recordings. in fact, it might even be more common with non-musicians, because musicians might specifically train themselves so well on the relative that they almost willfully disregard the absolute

hey there's a few questions i have about this song:
SLOW DOWN ANALYSIS

"look at the time, upon the wall
the clock is tellin it all wrong
you got to slow down
you got to slow down
slow it right off the wall
you got to slow down"
stop rushing.
ironically i couldn't, because i was under enormous time pressure to write the song. but that's a coincidence

"my hatis bent
oh, i got a bent hat
maybe i'll slow down
and straighten it out"
continued from the previous verse, when things aren't as they should be, the solution is to slow down, stop rushing-- that's what will right the wrongs.

in this particular song, "slow down" is a purely musical phrase. the lyrical content is actually not what i wanted to say at the time. and i tried very hard to come up with something else besides 'slow down'. but 'slow down' was the first and only good thing i could find that sounded right. to put it in context, 'slow down' was the first actual lyric i got, and the only other thing i knew was i wanted it to be a blues sequence (the chords going how they go, in those verse sections), with the 'title' being at that location (where 'slow down' is). and the first and only thing i could come up with was 'slow down', sung in that way. that's just the only thing that seemed to fit. i tried to come up with something else because it didn't 'seem' like the most interesting concept i could come up with. but i couldn't find anything else that worked as well. so i had to write the whole song around that

"and then twist it all around
then put it down"
doing things badly on purpose, and then letting them go for a while before you get back to straightening them out

"and i'm bobblin down 124th street
and i think i'm bobblin to a brighter day"
optimism

"and the radio's playing a different kind of music
and the universe is starting t o shake"
different music=change= brighter day
shake=change=brighter day

"look at the time, it's 12;30
i'm going to hell, and i'm late for it"
if you can people feel good about something bad, then you're bulletproof in life.

"but i'll slow down
and talk about it"
going back home lyrically to say 'slowing down's gonna right your wrongs.' 
this is your dissonant optimism at work: you're pretending you can SLOW DOWN to fix BEING LATE, but your conviction regarding this is so strong that you just might be right.

"and the world goes round and then comes back down"
could you talk about this a little?

sure. that's one of the worst lines in the song. you can see with most of this, i seemed to slip into this sort of "A A B" sectionality, where i do a couple of verses, then bounce to a bridge, then do a couple more verses, then another bridge, and back. i mean, it's not bad to do that, it's just in some points it kind of feels like it's on auto-pilot. It's likely that that line "world goes round and then comes back down" seems to represent the feeling of cycling through these song sections in this way.

i'll assume this line's meant to lead musically into the instrumental verse
